bibl.title: Letter from Samuel Taylor Darling to Frederick F. Russell, December 11, 1923

div1.p: Darling concludes after examining tissues that one man died of yellow fever and the other did not.

div1.head: Letter from Samuel Taylor Darling to Frederick F. Russell, December 11, 1923
div1.opener:
COPY
Leesburg, Ga.
Dec. 11-1923
Dr. F. F. Russell, General Director,
International Health Board,
61 Broadway, New York City.
Dear Dr. Russell:
div1.p:
I have examined the sections of tissue of the cases
of Jose Antonio Viviesca, 28 years of age, a citizen of Piedacuesta,
Colombia, and David Manrique, 52 years of age, citizen of Onzaga,
Colombia, referred to in Dr. Miller's letter from Bucaramanga, Colombia,
September 11th, 1923, and Miss Read's letters of October 31st and
November 14th.

The slides in question had been very kindly sent me by
Dr. Noguchi. As a result of the examination of these sections I am of
the opinion that Jose Antonio Viviesca died of yellow fever, but that
David Manrique did not. A brief description of the sections follows:

The section is rather pale and the architecture of the lobule
is ill defined, this is due to fatty metamorphosis and swelling of the
hepatic cells. There is a diffuse cellular necrosis of the hepatic cells
which contain much fat in the form of very small droplets. The nuclei
in places do not stain at all. In others they are somewhat swollen and
pale. There appears to be a slight proliferation of stroma cells and
there is a conspicuous collection of round cells in the portal spaces.
Scattered over the field are polynuclear leucocytes some of which are
fragmented giving the appearance of very minute cellular necroses. The
necrosis is diffuse and not particularly zonal in arrangement. Beneath
the capsule there is some hemorrhage and atrophy of the parenchyma due
to collapse of the lobules, possibly as a result of external compression.
The hepatic necrosis is extremely severe and while the lesions in my
experience are somewhat atypical they are undoubtedly due to the virus
of yellow fever.

The sections stain well with hematoxylin excepting for the
central zone, and the architecture of the lobule is well defined.
There is no hyaline necrosis of the hepatic cells. In the center of
the lobule there is a considerable amount of fat enclosed within the
hepatic cell but apparently not associated with hyaline necrosis. The
fat droplets are of small, medium and some of large size, surrounded
by a rather normal staining cytoplasm. There is some bile pigment-
ation of the hepatic cells, some granular pigment in the endothelial
cells and in the veins. There is also some extraneous pigment appar-
ently due to the fixing agent.

There is a good deal of cloudiness of the renal epithelium
which may be due to post-mortem changes. Some of the tubular epithelial
cells when stained with scarlet R. contain rather deeply staining globules,
some of which may be fat. There is no indication, from the sections, that
yellow fever is the cause of death in this case.
